titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. I rose this morning soon after six O’Clock, and employed the time with sufficient diligence in writing and reading untill Breakfast. At ten O’Clock I went with Mr Smith to the Roman Catholic Maltese Chapel, where we heard the Mass and funeral service performed for the late Commandeur de Maisonneuve— The music as usual was very excellent, and the voices of the singers both men and women admirable. I saw there among the company Mr Laval, who has returned with his family from Abo— They have abandoned their English and Swedish Expedition— I took the five Miles walk before dinner— Mr and Mrs Krehmer, Messrs: Harris, Lewis, Willing, Fisher, Redwood, Slade, Delprat and Tilden dined with us— Mr and Mrs Krehmer went away soon after dinner, having sickness which alarms them, in their young family. Their eldest daughter Sally was so much indisposed as not to be able to come— Mrs Krehmer however played on the Piano, and sung, about an hour after dinner before she left us— Several of the American Gentlemen stayed the Evening, and played Cards— I played several games of Chess with Mr Tilden— They all retired about Midnight.

2. Charles had a very bad Night, which of course allowed me no sleep. His cough was so troublesome that we were obliged to give him medecine in the Night— He was however excessively and incessantly restless untill the Morning. I rose about seven, and took the five Miles walk before Breakfast. Charles was better, through the day and in the Evening— The weather is yet very severe, and at the New Moon this day, has a fresh accession of cold— My thermometer this Evening was at -16. The Academy Register at — I attended the auction, but made no purchase— Some Mathematical and Astronomical instruments were sold; and some bad pictures. I had a morning visit from Mr J. W. Smith, Mr Ducorneau, and a Mr Wainwright— The two last, just arrived from Archangel, and Mr Smith from Moscow— I was so overwearied this Evening that I could scarcely keep up with Charles and his grammatical lesson— At 9 O’Clock I retired to bed.

3. Rose at 6 and after my ordinary reading attempted to take a walk; but there was a violent Snow-storm; a strong gale with the thermometer nearly at -15. A degree of cold, at which I scarcely ever before knew snow to fall— The wind, cold and snow combined together were too powerful for my hardihood, and after proceeding about half a mile, I turned back, and came home— The Snow-Storm continued untill the Evening; but the thermometer rose before Sunset to within 1 degree of the freezing point— It afterwards fell again to -10. I walked again before dinner, and encountered the Snow and Wind without difficulty, under the abatement of the Cold. I read prayers for the second Sunday after Christmas, and Sterne’s Sermon 14 upon the duty of Self-examination. He professes to indicate the reason why self-examination is so seldom efficacious, or followed by suitable improvement— There are some severe sarcasms, upon the auricular confession of the Romish Church; in a manner so ludicrous that I could scarcely forbear in reading it from laughing. There is likewise sharp censure upon the enthusiasm of the Methodists, of which however he speaks with more seriousness. Sterne appears to have thought that Ridicule was the best weapon of attack upon Popery; but he had not delicacy of mind enough to perceive that the pulpit was no place for levity. I resumed the attempt to write a series of Letters to my Son George; after an interval of more than a year; and began upon the 6th: Letter— Charles however took up my whole Evening, from dinner time— He was better in health; and in such a flow of Spirits that he chattered without ceasing.

4. The changes in the temperature of the atmosphere are very great and continual. My thermometer was this morning at -6 and this Evening again down to -15— I walked before Breakfast, and afterwards attended the Auction, of which this is the last day.— Charles is better, and employed the greatest part of my time this day— He rode out this morning after several days confinement. Catherine Johnson suffers with the rhumatism— We had Cards this Evening after tea.

5. Rose between 7 and 8 this Morning; after the dawn, but before full day-light. Took the short, or three miles walk before Breakfast. Had a morning visit from Mr Montréal; who is much distressed for his uncle Mr Raimbert. He had about 8 days ago a stroke of the palsy, and has almost entirely lost the use of his limbs on the right side— If there were a chance of recovering from this disease at any age, there could be little hope at his years— He is 75— They are also yet in a situation of alarm and difficulty occasioned by the War, and anticipate a probable necessity for them to quit this Country. I took Charles with me in the sledge, and went out to the frozen meat market, which was much crowded with People— We then crossed over to Ochta, and sent in at Mr Krehmer’s to enquire how his daughters were— They are ill of the scarlet fever. In the Evening, after reading one of Bouilly’s tales, I spent the rest of it in looking with Charles over the Prints I had purchased at the Auction— I received from the Grand Master of the Ceremonies, a Notification that the Court mourning would be suspended during the Christmas Holidays—that is, this and the three following days.— Catherine was confined the whole of this day to her bed.

6. Though I rose this morning before 6 and had accordingly four long hours untill breakfast time, I wasted two of them upon trifling occupations; and did not redeem them in the course of the day— The other two were employed in reading, and at the morning walk. I stopp’d at the Roman Catholic, Jesuit’s Church, where there was a small congregation, and Priests busy, at three of the four altars—
but it was at an interval between the several services of the day; which is the Russian Christmas— I had a visit from Mr Cutts who arrived two days since from Archangel— He is upon his return to America, and I promised to obtain for him a Courier’s Passport; and give him dispatches— Mr Harris also was here this morning and again in the Evening. He invited the whole family to dine with him on the Russian New-Year’s day— I rode out with Charles in the sleigh; to Kammenoi-Ostroff— The whole Evening excepting while Mr Harris was here, I was engaged with him— Catherine was still confined to her bed.

7. I endeavoured, but without success to be more industrious than yesterday. Mr Delprat called upon me to enquire if I could procure for him a Courier’s Passport to go to Vienna— I rode out in the Sleigh with Charles as far as the Nevsky Monastery; and after returning I took a second walk— Although Charles was not disposed to pursue any of his studies this Evening, and left me to my own leisure, I was too much overpowered by drowsiness to make any profitable use of the time— At the close of the Evening I played Chess with Mr Smith— The day was chiefly consumed in reading some English Newspapers sent me by Mr Harris— Catherine cannot yet leave her chamber.

8. Captain Bates called upon me and brought me a letter from a Mr Meyer, an American Citizen, now at Riga; requesting me to procure for him a Passport to come to St: Petersburg— I referred him to Mr Harris, who makes all the applications of this kind. Mr Plummer and Mr Cabot also paid me a morning visit— Mr Cabot came from Archangel with Mr Cutts— He is a son of the late Mr Andrew Cabot, whom I last saw in London in 1796 and who soon after died there. I walked before Breakfast and before dinner, and employed a few hours of the day in writing— Sent a note to Count Romanzoff requesting a Courier’s Passport for Mr Cutts. In the Evening, Charles having again allowed me the leisure, I finished reading Durand’s French Translation of Cicero’s Academics— These are two fragments of separate works on the same Subject. A defence of the Academic philosophy, of what was called the new School. They are both in the form of Dialogues; the first between Cicero, Atticus, and Varro, to whom it is dedicated; and the second between Cicero, Catulus, Lucullus, and Hortensius— The first consists of a short and rapid History of the Academic philosophy from Socrates its founder to Carneades; but the fragment breaks off just as a magnificent panegyric upon Carneades begins— The second is a discussion of the academic principle, universal doubt, which Lucullus attacks as a follower of Zeno the Stoic, and which Cicero defends— There is in this second book a passage p. 191. which together with another in Plutarch, first suggested to Copernicus his system of Astronomy, in opposition to that of Ptolemy— It says that Hicetas of Syracuse thought the Sun, Moon, and all the Stars were stationary, and the Earth revolved round them: and that the same doctrine is advanced though more obscurely in Plato’s Timaeus— An example what extensive inferences genius and meditation can draw from the slightest hints— I must compare this translation of the Academics with the original.

9. Mr Cutts called upon me again this morning.— I wrote a Note to Count Löwenhielm, requesting his Passport for him, to enable him to pass as a Courier through Sweden— Wrote a little before Breakfast; but I scarcely know how the rest of the day slipp’d away— Charles employed the whole Evening. He read one of Bouilly’s tales; and played about an hour with the grammatical Counters— Catherine Johnson still keeps her bed, with a severe attack of the rhumatism.

10. I received from Count Löwenhielm, a Passport for Mr Cutts, and a note requesting to know when he would go, and expressing a wish to send letters by him— I answered the note, with Offers to send by Mr Cutts any thing which the Count may wish to forward— Rode with Charles in the Sleigh to Krasna Kabak, 5 Versts on the Peterhoff road— Mr Harris paid us an Evening visit.— I read prayers for the first Sunday after the Epiphany, and Sterne’s Sermon upon Job’s expostulation with his wife;—or on the efficacy of religion to relieve us in time of trouble. He gives three conjectural explanations of the wife’s advice to Job, to curse God and die; which after all I believe it is best to take according to the plain import of the words. Altogether it is one of the most serious and most excellent Sermons of the collection; though as I have observed of them generally there is a falling off towards the close which weakens the impression of the whole discourse. This is one of the marks of hasty composition not to say of carelessness, which is chargeable upon most if not all of them— His genius seems to throw out a vivid blaze, and then to burn out like a faggot fire. I omitted reading a Sermon of Mayhew’s but employed the time in writing to George; without however finishing the letter.

11. Had a morning visit from Mr Montreal— Received a note from Count Romanzoff requesting the postponement for one day of Mr Cutts’s departure, and promising to send the Passport for him to-morrow. Madame Colombi called to see Mrs Adams, and left several papers upon which she requested a Certificate by me, as a neutral Minister, for the authentication of Notarial documents to be used in France— But I did not know precisely what certificate it was, she wanted— Her Sister Frederica Bode dined with us, and on going to her house in the Evening told her of my uncertainty— Mr Lys, the chief Clerk in the compting house came in the Evening, and brought a form of the Certificate wanted— It was of the Notary’s authority and signature. Catherine is still confined to her chamber, and the greater part of the time to her bed— Dr Galloway sat some time with us this Evening. I finished at last my letter to George

12. Rose this Morning at 5, and found constant employment untill the hour of breakfast; but the weather having again grown cold, I could write only part of the morning— After breakfast I carried the papers for Countess Colombi to her house— Then went to the plate-shops; thence to Mr Meyer’s, on my usual errand there; and finally to Mr Raimbert’s— I found him lame; but better than on his first attack— His head, and speech have not been at-all affected; and his Spirits are more cheerful than might have been expected— From his house I walked home; making a circuit round the Fontanka, and through the Nevsky Perspective— Received from Count Romanzoff, Mr Cutt’s Passport, and a packet to be sent by him for Mr Daschkoff. In the Evening Mr Proud called upon me, with an English Newspaper, of 20. December, containing President Madison’s Message to Congress of 4. November— It blasts again the hopes I had entertained of Peace. We had Evening visits also from Mr Harris, Mr Lewis and Mr Willing— Catherine is yet very unwell—confined to her chamber, and in a great measure to her bed— I read this morning several Sections of Voltaire’s Philosophie de l’Histoire, prefixed to his Essai sur les Moeurs et l’Esprit des Nations— The whole he says was written for the illustre Marquise du Chatelêt— It is quite philosophical enough for a Lady’s perusal; and has passages too disgustingly obscene, for a man of any sense of shame— His infidelity is always malicious; and venomous as a serpent. But he is always lively, ingenious, and surprizingly learned— The rapidity of his conception, and the vigour of his retention are prodigious— His cavils at the Bible are ludicrous; and to my mind contemptible.

13. I waked and rose this morning, about half past 3 O’Clock, and finding it so early, returned to bed, and had the unusual good fortune of falling asleep again; and finally rose about seven— The cold weather having again set in, I did not walk before Breakfast— By the time the Sun had risen;—the Russian New-Year announced itself by the usual visits from the Court Servants and others to present their felicitations and receive their donations— Mr Harris sent an elegant present to the Ladies— Mr Cutts came and took his Passports and dispatches, intending to commence his journey this Evening— At Noon I went with Mr Smith, and attended the Te Deum at the Kazan Church on the occasion of the total expulsion of the Enemy from the Russian territories— The Empresses, and other members of the Imperial family now here were present— The Te Deum was preceded by a Mass— It finished between 2 and 3. O’Clock— I walked about an hour, and with Mrs Adams, Mr Smith, and Charles dined at Mr Harris’s— Catherine being still confined to her bed could not go. I came home early in the Evening with Charles, and then returned and finished the Evening with Cards and Supper at Mr Harris’s— We came home about Midnight— Catherine was quite ill— The severity of the cold, and the warmth of Mr Harris’s apartments affected me so powerfully that I was obliged to come out with Charles— Messrs: Lewis, Willing, Slade, Tilden and Dimond, and Calhoun formed together with our family the party.

14. Rose this morning about 8 O’Clock, by daylight— The first time since the days began to lengthen— Walked only once, and that before dinner— Charles was so much engaged with his present of pewter Soldiers, given him by Mr Harris, that I allowed him the whole Evening with them. I read a few pages in Voltaire’s introduction to the Essai sur les Moeurs, but was soon overtaken by drowsiness and obliged to desist. I retired quite early to bed— Mrs Adams was called up in the Night to Catherine, who was extremely ill— Mr Fisher paid us a visit this morning—

15. Rose again between 5 and 6; but I have suspended my early morning walks owing to the severity of the Cold. Mrs Adams was suddenly taken, and violently ill all day— She was bled— Her illness is of an alarming nature, and aggravated by the distress of mind occasioned by the heavy calamities which in a short space of time have befallen us— I walked before dinner— Had morning visits from Mr Delprat, Mr Plummer, and Mr Proud; and in the Evening from Mr Harris— Catherine is still very ill.

16. Rose about 5. O’Clock, and was employed untill breakfast time in preparing an Index to my public letter Book. Vol. 1. but I was twice obliged to leave the work by the coldness of my chamber, and the numbness of my fingers— Mr Montreal paid me a morning visit— I took my usual walk before dinner. The rest of the day I passed in my wife’s chamber, by her bed-side; and the Evening while she slept, with Charles and his toys— Mrs Adams was confined the whole day to her bed; and her sister being alike confined to her chamber, I feel myself called by a duty to devote as much of my time as I can spare to soothe and comfort my wife in her distressed state— Her Condition is the same as that in which repeated misfortunes have befallen her, and she is again threatened in the same manner— Her Spirits are withal deeply affected; and I hope the time which I consume in attending to her and upon her, will not be chargeable upon the score of idleness. It does however in some degree interfere with the due and timely discharge of some other duties, and calls upon me to provide for a sufficient number of morning hours in which I may employ the solitude of my own chamber.

17. Mrs Adams who was apparently much better this morning, had another turn of extreme illness, in the course of the day, and a very severe return of alarming symptoms in the Evening. They afterwards partly subsided again— Catherine is yet confined to her chamber— I read prayers for the second Sunday after the Epiphany, and Sterne’s Sermon upon the character of Shimei— In the Evening I also read one Sermon of Mayhew’s, exhorting Young Men to be sober-minded— The Academy’s Register of the Thermometer was at -22: 4 degrees colder than it was through the whole of last Winter; or than it has hitherto been this Season— I walked before the dinner, and passed the remainder of the day in my wife’s chamber— My Coachman was taken up by the Police, for going into the Streets in a woman’s dress— I wrote a note to General Gorgoly, and obtained his liberation.

18. This is the Russian festival of the Epiphany, and the day of the benediction of the Waters of the Neva; but the Emperor being absent, and no parade of the troops, the foreign Ministers were not invited to attend the ceremony.— I had a long and very serious conversation with Mr Smith, who finally avowed a disposition to do right. I received letters from Gothenburg and from England with an account of the capture of the British frigate Macedonian by the American frigate United States. Mr Lewis and Mr Dimond shortly after called upon me with the same information. Mrs Krehmer paid a visit to Mrs Adams— Mr Harris called in the morning, and Mr Brandel in the Evening, but I did not see them— There is very little abatement in the severity of the Cold— I walked before dinner, and spent the Evening with Mrs Adams, in her chamber, to which she was the whole day confined. Saw Catherine for the first time since last Friday.

19. Mrs Adams was so far recovered as to dine with us at table; but the remainder of the day principally kept her chamber. I finished making the Index to the first Volume of my Public Letter-Book— Walked before dinner only— I had a conversation with Catherine, and made to her the proposal, offered by Mr Smith; to which she desired me to express to him her consent. He had made the same in writing to herself— Dr Galloway was here in the Evening.

20. Had a long morning visit from Mr Harris, who has received a letter from his nephew dated Falmouth, in England, 18. December. He was to embark the next day in a Cartel Packet, for New-York; so that we may hope he will reach Washington before the end of this month. I received from the Grand-Master of the Ceremonies a Notification that the funeral of the Prince of Oldenburg would be the day after to-morrow— The service to be performed at the Lutheran Church of St: Peter’s— That seats, would be prepared for the Corps Diplomatique, who would attend or not, at their option— The Church is fitted up in great State— As I walked through the Perspective I went into the Church-yard; but the crowd was so great that I did not attempt to go into the Church— I had a further but not a definitive conversation with Mr. Smith— The Evening I employed in preparing an Index to my private Letter-Book—an occupation which will take up five or six Evening’s more.

21. I had scarcely any sleep the whole Night, but did not rise untill between 8 and 9 this Morning— Mrs: Adams was severely and alarmingly ill the greater part of the day and Evening— Catherine is yet so ill that there are no immediate prospects of abatement to her disorder— My own health is deeply affected by this state of things, and anxieties for the future weigh upon me with a pressure known only to almighty God— His aid alone can prepare me for the prospect before me, can mitigate its rigour, and enable me to support that which he shall not see fit to avert— The weather which had a little moderated, again became in the course of the day as cold as it has yet been; and during the greatest part of the day the cold prevented me from writing— I walked however before dinner; and read in the Evening as long as the weakness of my eyes would allow— The Messenger from the Department of the Ceremonies brought us tickets for admission to-morrow at the Church, where the funeral service for the Prince of Oldenburg is to be performed.

22. At Noon we went and attended at the funeral ceremony for the Prince of Oldenburg, at the Lutheran Church of St: Peter’s. The Ceremony consisted of a funeral Sermon, in the German language, and two hymns, sung with accompaniment of instrumental music, before and after the Sermon— The Church was hung round entirely, including the cieling with black Cloth. The Coffin was placed in the Centre of the Church, raised upon a stage of three high steps, and covered with a canopy of crimson cloth, and white silk; surmounted at the four corners with tufts of ostrich, plumes.— Four large wooden lackered Urns with clusters of Candlesticks disposed round them were placed at the four corners of the stage upon which the coffin was raised; and a row of large wax-candles ranged round the first floor of the stage— The ceremony lasted about an hour and a half— None of the Imperial family, or of the Prince’s family were present; but the Ministers of the Country, and the foreign Ministers were generally there— It was the coldest day there has been this winter— I walked before dinner— In the Evening I was so much overpowered with drowsiness; having had several Nights almost sleepless, that I retired to bed before Nine O’Clock— Mrs Adams kept her bed the whole day, and Catherine’s illness increases in severity— Dr: Galloway was here in the Evening.

23. The weather has at length again moderated, and my thermometer at Noon was at -8. a temperature which coming upon that of the preceding days feels as soft and mild as Spring— I had a further, and a very solemn conversation with Mr Smith, who professed a sincere and earnest wish to do what is just and right. I walked before dinner; and in the Evening was again for about an hour oppressed with drowsiness beyond my power to withstand— The remainder of the day I passed almost entirely by my wife’s bed side.— She and Catherine, are still both confined to their chambers— God grant me in this day of trial, the Spirit of integrity, and of Fortitude which it requires, and enable me fully to discharge my private and domestic duties, without absorbing the time indispensable to the fulfilment of those due to the public.

24. Morning visit from Mr: Montreal; who brought me the Russian Statement of the prisoners they have made, and of the killed in the French armies, from the commencement of the War, untill the return of the Russians to Willna. They make the loss of the Enemy, upwards of three hundred thousand Men— I took a long walk before dinner— Mrs Adams and Catherine being both a little better dined with us; but my wife was obliged immediately afterwards to return to bed— I read prayers for the third Sunday after the Epiphany, and Sterne’s Sermon upon the Story of Hezekiah and the Messengers; preached before the Earl of Hertford at Paris in 1763. Read also one of Mayhew’s Sermons to young Men; and gave the Evening from dinner untill tea-time to Charles.

25. The Empress’s birth day— But no sort of public notice was taken of it— Not even a suspension of the Court Mourning.— Mr Lawler called upon me this morning, and informed me, that he intended going next week for England. I promised to obtain for him a Courier’s Passport. I have not yet been able to resume the regular course of my occupations— The cares and distresses of my family, and the agitation of mind into which they have brought me, overcome almost all my habits, and my firmest resolutions of industry.— I read this Evening a few sections of Voltaire’s Philosophie de l’Histoire; the whole purpose of which is to discredit the holy Scriptures— I have read it before, but without seeing it in so detestable a light, as I now behold it— The perpetual repetition of his respect and veneration for the Bible and the Christian Religion, is disgusting—the filthy obscenity which pollutes almost every page of it is still more so—the profound and bitter malice against the Jews which is constantly bursting forth is ridiculous— But the attacks direct and indirect upon the Scriptures which pervade the whole work are managed with address, and urged in a manner calculated to make impression upon weak minds— My wife is still confined to her bed, and Catherine again to her chamber.

26. The weather having moderated to about -12 degrees, I again this morning took my long walk before Breakfast.— Mr Harris, and Mr Slade with a Captain Mayo, paid me morning visits— Captain Mayo is master of one of the American vessels lying at Cronstadt, which he leaves here, and is going to Sweden and perhaps to America— Mrs Adams and Catherine were again confined the whole of this day to their chambers— I passed great part of it by my wife’s bed side— In the Evening I read several Sections of Voltaire’s ribaldry which he calls the Philosophy of History.

27. The days have so far lengthened that I now occasionally rise by day-light— This morning however I wrote some time by the candle. Mrs. Adams was confined the greatest part of the day to her bed; but the family all dined together— Catherine is I hope recovering— I walked before dinner, and in the Evening finished reading Voltaire’s Philosophie de l’Histoire— There is something ludicrous in his perpetual efforts to exalt the Egyptian, Babylonian and Chinese monarchies at the expence of the poor Jews; and something absurd beyond measure in his pretence that all these idolatrous Nations really worshipped one only God the creator and governor of the world—while on the other hand in the face of every page, and every line of the Bible, he would persuade us that the Jews themselves considered their God Adonaï—or Jao only as a deity like the Moloch, and Chemos and Dagon and Baal of their neighbours. The best refutation of Voltaire’s cynical but ingenious infidelity, is the assiduous Study of the Scriptures which he would discredit. They amply vindicate themselves to the mind of every man who reads them with sincere purpose and serious attention.

28. Mr Lawler called upon me this Morning to inform me that Captain Mayo had applied to him to go in company with him as far as Stockholm; but that it would not suit his convenience; he having made his arrangements to go alone— Mr Lewis and Mr Willing also paid me a visit and had received several letters from Gothenburg, from England, and from America, of very late dates, with news— Multitudes of rumours; but nothing of importance which we had not heard before— Excepting the declared blockade of Chesapeake Bay, and Delaware River, by the English Government— All prospects of Peace more remote than ever.— My family being in a state of a little more tranquility, and my wife able to leave her bed, I had time this day for writing— The whole Evening I gave to
Charles, who read to me one of Bouilly’s tales, and the rest of the time untill tea, played with the grammatical Counters.— I began and read a very few pages in the second Volume of Voltaire’s Essai sur les Moeurs et l’Esprit des Nations

29. Although the thermometer was this morning at -I walked about an hour before Breakfast— The day continued so cold that I wrote with much difficulty— But I wrote—great part of the morning, and again in the Evening— I took a second walk before dinner, and in the Evening read a few pages of Voltaire’s Essai sur les Moeurs.— Catherine was again confined to her chamber. There is an infectious distemper about the City; and an order has issued from the Police to use Onions and tar in the houses; and to give notice to the Police of every person who may fall sick in any house.

30. Mr Dimond called upon me this morning— He is going away in a short time; and came to ask me to procure for him a Courier’s Passport; which I promised him to do. Mr Harris also paid me a Morning visit, and brought me the English Courier, for the last week in December, and for 1. January— These Papers contain much news, and not a little speculation concerning America and American affairs. The capture of the Macedonian Frigate; following close upon that of the Guerriere, has given the English Lords of the Ocean cause for serious reflection— It gives the same to us; and to my Heart, motives of ardent Gratitude to God, that our National character has been thus honourably maintained— I pray that it may continue to be supported with equal Glory; and that it may turn the Hearts of our Enemies to Peace— I passed much of the day in reading these Papers; and the rest in writing to America.— Thermometer this morning -25 Evening -23:8.

31. Mrs. Adams was again very unwell the whole day— The severity of the weather still increases— I walked before dinner; and wrote as much as I could—that is, very little— I read prayers for the fourth Sunday after the Epiphany— Sterne’s Sermon against rash and censorious Judgments, upon the Story of the Levite and his Concubine; and Mayhew’s 13th: Sermon to Young Men— Sterne must have had some reference to his own adventures, in writing upon the case of the Levite— His Discourse is a sort of Apology for incontinence— It has the beauties and the vices of his manner more strongly marked perhaps than any other in the collection— Such a strong compound of the ludicrous and the pathetic, that in reading it, I was more than once unable to refrain from laughter and from tears— There is something inexpressibly fascinating in this manner, but its morality is loose and equivocal— The practice of the preacher is the best comment upon his precepts— Every tree is known by its fruits.

Day. Differs little from that of the last Month—except that the condition of my family has effectually broken up the regularity of my rising hours; and the steadiness of my occupations— I still read as usual before Breakfast— Still hear Charles in the Morning, and sometimes, though seldom in the Evening— Still write, a little in this Book; and walk five or six miles every day— My household concerns are also as yet managed with as much order as I can keep in them; and I write letters from time to time— But sickness and sorrows not without cause, absorb many of my hours, and break through every purpose of profitable employment which I should wish to accomplish— I pray that I may possess my Soul in Patience, and that if it be the Will of Heaven days of more tranquility may be reserved for me hereafter.
Thermometer. Morning -28. Noon -24:5. Eve -23.
